Purpose

This guideline is aimed at all health care professionals working in the acute hospital setting and community who share in the provision of antenatal, intrapartum and postpartum care, including midwives, obstetricians, anaesthetists, paediatric and neonatal staff, ultrasound department staff, maternity care assistants and trainees in above professions.
This guideline is intended to assist professionals in providing timely evidence based practice, ensuring optimum care to the mother, partner and family, and respect for baby.

This guideline reflects advancing clinical knowledge and social awareness. The information is designed to aid practitioners in making decisions about appropriate obstetric and midwifery care but should not be construed as dictating an exclusive course of treatment or procedure – variations in practice may be warranted based on the individual needs of the women..

These guidelines should be used in conjunction with checklist one or checklist two and with the assistance of the associated flowcharts which will ensure all aspects of care are documented and completed. (Refer to Appendix A, B, KK, LL, MM, NN)
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is
fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix OO)
Aims

Parents should be treated with respect and dignity and their loss recognised and acknowledged. They should be given time and information to enable them to feel in control where possible, and care should be patient led where possible.

Communication should be clear, sensitive and honest – in verbal and written formats (Written formats should be in patients own language) (Refer to the guideline for ‘Interpretation and translation policy' ; register number 09127) (Refer to the Trust's policy on ‘Breaking Bad News'; register number 07064)
A midwife should be allocated to give one to one care to the patient for the duration of the shift to maximise continuity.

The parents should be given reassurance that they will be offered investigations to try and establish the cause of the death of their baby, but need to be sensitively informed that it is not unusual for the cause of death to remain unexplained.
Clinical needs must be met alongside psychological, cultural and spiritual needs.
Appropriate follow-up care must be individually tailored to each patient.
All professionals caring for the family must be informed of the pregnancy outcome to avoid contacting the patient unaware that the pregnancy has ended.
All care given should be clearly and contemporaneously documented.
Definitions of Pregnancy loss

Medical termination of pregnancy (med. TOP) is the process of ending a pregnancy with medication for fetal abnormality, usually below < 23 weeks and 6 days but can also be indicated later on in the pregnancy. Please consider using the term “compassionate induction” when talking to the parents about the difficult decision they have had to make, rather than termination which can carry stigma and cause further distress.

Spontaneous miscarriage is spontaneous delivery below  weeks and 6 days without medication. A missed miscarriage is the term applied to intra-uterine death before 23 weeks and 6 days which requires medication, or surgery (if < 13 weeks) to deliver. Any loss, at any gestation, is devastating for the parents and the use of language surrounding loss has a huge impact and must be chosen carefully.

Stillbirth (SB) is a spontaneous delivery of an infant with no signs of life or intra-uterine death requiring induction >  weeks and 0 days. It may be expected, after interuterine death (IUD) is confirmed in pregnancies over 24 weeks gestation, or occur unexpectedly at point of delivery requiring emergency attendance and attempted resuscitation by midwives and paediatric team.

Neonatal Death (NND) is a baby born of any gestation which shows signs of life; for a death certificate to be issued the same doctor needs to see the baby alive and after death therefore call for urgent medical review of any live birth, regardless of gestation. This can be obstetricians before  weeks and 6 days (unless concerns over gestational maturity and needing paediatric assessment and ideally paediatricians after  weeks and 0 days (08051 Child Death Review & Rapid Response Policy refers). If a doctor is unable to review the baby when signs of life exist, the doctor signing the death certificate will have to liaise with the coroner and Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages (Registrar for B, D & M) before completing the death certificate. All NND must be reported officially to the coroner via the “Coroner referral form” (Appendix W) and emailed by the doctor within  hours.
Antenatal Management for Medical Termination for Fetal Abnormality
(Compassionate Induction) (Red paperwork File Required)

The patient and her partner should be seen by the Antenatal and Newborn Screening team (or Labour Ward staff and on-duty Obstetric Registrar if out of clinic hours). Feticide is recommended if over  weeks and 6 days gestation and must be discussed. Patients are usually referred to University College, London (UCL) for feticide as it is not carried out within MEHT.

If parents decline feticide a clear plan must be drawn up by obstetric registrar and paediatric registrar/consultant before commencing termination of pregnancy in case a live birth occurs, as any fetus born with signs of life will have the right to appropriate care and treatment. Any baby born at any gestation with signs of life and then dies will be classified as a neonatal death and registration of birth and death must take place.

Patients under  weeks (i.e.  weeks and 6 days or less gestation for medical termination will usually be cared for on Gosfield Ward ; 17 weeks and 0 days gestation and above will be cared for on Labour Ward.
An Obstetric Consultant or Registrar must see the patient to answer questions and prescribe medications as per protocol. (Refer to Appendix C)
Please commence the red folder of paperwork for all maternity cases  weeks and 6 days
and under. These can be found on labour ward in the stationary cupboard. A blue folder is needed if 24 weeks and over. It contains the check list and all consent forms, and patient
leaflets required throughout the whole process. If a baby is born alive and then dies please
add paperwork from the yellow neonatal death folder.
Form HSA1 and HSA4 must be signed by Obstetric Registrar or Consultant as a legal requirement for termination of pregnancy and prior to procedure. (Refer to Appendix D and Appendix E)
If feticide is undertaken, a photocopy of the HSA1 should be in the patient notes from the hospital that initiated the termination with feticide.
HSA1 remains in the patients notes, HSA4 is completed and sent to the maternity secretaries office who will then send it to the Chief Medical Officer within 14 days.
Consent Form 3 must be completed by the patient and doctor for mifepristone / misoprostol.

Mifepristone/misoprostol patient information leaflet is given to the patient along with a full explanation which should be documented in the patient's healthcare records (Refer to ‘Guideline for the use of mifepristone, misoprostol and prostin in a termination of pregnancy'. Register number 06032)

Mifepristone and procholperizine should be admininstered as per protocol. (Refer to ‘Guideline for the use of mifepristone, misoprostol and prostin in a termination of pregnancy'. Register number 06032)
Written information should be given to the parents in the appropriate language i.e. ARC booklet. (Refer to the guideline for ‘Interpretation and translation policy' ; register number 09127)

Checklist One should be commenced (and occaisionally after  weeks of pregnancy where there is documented evidence of fetal death before 23 weeks and 6 days also use Checklist One) (Refer to Appendix A)
Fetal loss investigations are not required for a Termination of Pregnancy unless indicated by the Fetal Medicine team or consultant.
Funeral arrangements information should be given if requested\appropriate. (Refer to Appendix O)

Arrange the date and time to go to Labour Ward, or if under  weeks – Gosfield Ward, hours after mifepristone has been administered. The Screening Midwife should ensure that the patient has a contact number for labour ward in case an earlier admission is desired, medical attention is required or the patient has further questions before her re-admission.

Labour Ward should be informed of the admission time and date ; and patient details entered into the Labour Ward Diary or inform Gosfield Ward of expected admission if <17 weeks. Please keep the folder of paperwork in the patients notes that are retained on labour ward for their return.
Antenatal Management for Spontaneous delivery < 24+0 weeks gestation
(Red Paper Work file Required with Yellow file if NND)
Patients admitted via The Emergency Department 16+6 weeks and under gestation will usually go to Gosfield Ward, and women  weeks and over gestation, will be transferred directly to Labour Ward.
The parents should be given as much information as possible about what to expect if the delivery occurs or is anticipated.

Parents should be seen by the paediatric registrar if baby will be on the threshold of viability i.e. over 23 weeks, or in some circumstances over  weeks, to give parents a realistic prognosis of baby's survival and what can and cant be done with regards to resusitation and palative care. Ideally this needs to be done prior to the baby being born, if this is not possible effective communication from the paediatric/obstetric team at the time is vital to manage parents expectations.
The obstetric registrar should see the couple to review the medical situation, answer questions, prescribe analgesia and other medication if indicated i.e. antibiotics

If a live birth occurs at any gestation, medical assistance must be called. The same doctor needs to see the baby alive and after death to be able to complete the Medical Certificate of Neonatal Death, and cremation forms if required. If a doctor can't review the baby when signs of life exist, the doctor signing the death certificate will have to liaise with the coroner and Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages before completing the death certificate (Registrar for B, D and M). If there is any chance a baby could be born alive in this situation two midwives should be present, and any signs of life documented clearly in the notes by both practitioners. If no signs of life observed please document so.
Antenatal Management for Intrauterine death <  weeks and 6 days
gestation (Late Miscarriage) and >  weeks and 0 days gestation
(stillbirth) (Red or Blue Paperwork file required)
(Refer to Appendix LL, MM)
The patient and her partner should be seen by the Antenatal and Newborn Screening Co- ordinator if death is confirmed in the ultrasound department by the sonographers.

Contact the birth partner requested by the patient as soon as possible, to be with her if she is alone. Repeat all the information again, once patient is supported by her chosen partner/s and inform the Bereavement Midwife.

If an IUD is suspected on Labour or Antenatal Ward, the ultrasound scanning machine should be used to confirm the fetal death as soon as possible, this must be be followed by further confirmation either by another Obstetrician or in the Ultrasound Department with the patient being accompanied by a Midwife (partner or friend if the patient requests). If out of hours the obsetric registrar or consultant will use the Labour Ward ultrasound scanning machine and depending on clinical picture ; a scan may or may not be carried out in the Ultrasound Department once open. To avoid delay and uncertainty for the patient, if a departmental scan can not take place it is acceptable to have another appropriately trained senior doctor (this may be the Consultant on call) to confirm the IUD and document clearly in the notes. Administration of Mifepristone can then take place without delay after the second scan if the parents so wish.
Once a fetal death is confirmed the Obstetric Registrar, Bereavement Midwife, Antenatal
and Newborn Screening Midwife or Consultant will discuss induction options, this may be

with mifepristone, misoprostol, prostin or syntocinon. The woman will be given a verbal explanation and written information. (Refer to ‘Guideline for the use of Mifepristone, Misoprostol and Prostin in a Termination of Pregnancy'; register number 06032)
All discussions and decisions should be documented in the healthcare record.
Give the patient time to ask questions and privacy if she wishes.

Commence the correct fetal loss paperwork file – red for 23 weeks and 6 days and under, and blue for  weeks and over. The folder contains the checklist, patient leaflets and consent forms required for the whole process.
Fetal loss bloods including Kliehauer should be taken on diagnosis of an IUD – all tests required are detailed in the fetal loss folder and a fetal loss profile request is available on Review.
Anti D is required for Rhesus Negative ladies on diagnosis of IUD as this is a sensitising event.
Written information should be given to the parents in the appropriate language i.e. Sands leaflet and Broomfield patient leaflet, found in the front of the paperwork folder.
The obstetric registrar should see the parents again if they wish, answer any further questions and prescribe medication as per protocol. (Refer to appendix C)
Consent form 3 is required for an induction with mifepristone or/ and misoprostol

If the patient is well enough to go home to await the effects of mifepristone, then the date and time for induction should be arranged with the patient by the Midwife, Bereavement Midwife, Antenatal and Newborn Screening Midwife or Obstetric Registrar. If the patient does not want an immediate induction, ensure she and her family are aware that there is a 48 hour gap between the mifepristone and misoprostol administration.
The induction procedure should be commenced as per protocol.
(Refer to ‘Guideline for the use of Mifepristone, Misoprostol and Prostin in a Termination of Pregnancy'; register number 06032)
Checklist one or two should be commenced depending on gestation. (Refer to appendix A and B)
Funeral and spiritual care information should be given if requested/appropriate at this time. (Refer to the following link: http://meht-intranet/documents/patient-information/ )

Arrange the date and time for the patient to return to Labour Ward 48 hours after the mifepristone administration. The contact number for Labour Ward should be given in case an earlier admission is desired, medical attention is required, or the patient has questions before her re-admission. The Maternity Bereavement Team number should also be given at this point.
Bereaved parents are entitled to free parking and a ‘Blossom Suite' permit can be found in the front of the paperwork file.

Labour Ward should be informed of the admission time and date, and patient details entered into the Labour Ward Diary. Fetal loss paperwork file is to be kept with the ladies notes on labour ward to be continued on her return.
Management of an intrapartum Stillbirth –  weeks and above (Blue
paper work file required)

If a woman presents at St Peters Midwife-led Unit, Maldon; or WJC, Braintree Midwife-led Unit or in the community with suspected fetal loss, the mode of transport should be assessed and determined when taking into consideration the stage of labour. Patient should not be travelling on her own.

If a stillbirth is anticipated use checklist two (refer to appendix B). Induction will not be indicated if the patient's labour is spontaneous but may be augmented by artificial rupture of the membranes or with syntocinon. Discuss the individual management with an obstetric registrar or consultant on call.
For an unexpected stillbirth (intrapartum) and neonatal death, summon help via emergency bell as soon as problem identified as follows :
Instigate a CODE BLUE call on Ext  stating place of emergency
Leave the umbilical cord long on the infant's side to facilitate resucitation
Retain the placenta for examination
(Send to histopathology in formulin, with request form if no postmortem required, or send with baby in a dry pot to the mortary if a postmortem is being undertake.

Explain to parents that assistance is required to resuscitate baby and that you will give them more details as soon as is possible. (Refer to the guideline for ‘Neonatal resuscitation' ; register number 07074)
Complete the delivery once an assisting midwife and paediatricians are present to care for baby. Take cord blood for all investigations, as well as cord pH if possible. (Refer to Appendix G)
As soon as possible, ideally at a time when other blood samples are required, take blood from the mother for maternal investigations into stillbirth. (Refer to Appendix F)
Ensure all care is documented in maternal health care records as contemperaneously as possible by the responsible practitioner.
Make the patient physically comfortable and offer analgesia.
Ensure a midwife is present to offer emotional support when the stillbirth or neonatal death is confirmed by the medical staff.

Maternal death and baby dying within uterus ; in such circumstances the official definition of a stillbirth does not include the removal of a dead baby from its deceased mother. This is because the post mortem is being carried out on the mother rather than the dead baby. Therefore, registration of a baby in these circumstances over  weeks gestation as a death or stillbirth is not legally required. This advice has been given by Registrar General (Office for National Statistics). However, consideration must be shown to the wishes of the family. (Refer to the guideline for ‘Management of maternal death'; register number 06028)

A medical practitioner may issue a death certificate for the dead baby as stillborn if over 24 weeks gestation at post mortem. Most Registrars of Births, Deaths and Marriages will comply but local policies in this respect should be checked in order to prevent confusion and further distress for the family.

As the majority of pathologists will tend to remove the baby from the mother's body at post- mortem it is sensible for the local stillbirth / neonatal death procedure to be followed whether the baby is to be registered as a death or not. It would also be helpful for the normal MBRRACE procedure to be followed.
Intrapartum Management for all losses on Labour Ward

A pregnancy loss paperwork file which includes the checklist should be commenced as soon as the pregnancy loss is identified. Checklist one for medical termination/miscarriage 23 weeks and 6 days and under, and Checklist two for stillbirth 24 weeks and over including neonatal death at any gestation. This ensures that staff complete all necessary paperwork and investigations. It also serves to communicate what has been done, or is still to do, in conjunction with the maternal notes.

Care should be given in the Blossom Suite whenever possible. This is a room set up to accomodate families at this difficult time, with a double bed and sofa area to spend quality time with their baby. If required there is space to accomodate a hospital bed as well.

Physical care in labour will be dictated by the patient's clinical requirements and gestation. (Refer to guideline for the management of normal labour and prolonged labour in low risk patients' Register number 09079)

All management of labour must be discussed with senior medical staff. If fetal death is thought to be secondary to serious maternal complications of pregnancy, notably abruption, pre-eclampsia or sepsis, the patient's management must be discussed with the obstetric consultant on call as urgent delivery may be required. A small number of patients may require a caesarean section if the above conditions are diagnosed.
The potential risk of developing coagulation defect, if delivery is delayed when intrauterine death is known to have occured, should be considered when induction of labour is necessary.
It is advisable to leave membranes to break spontaneously although in some circumstances artificial rupture of the membranes may be necessary to augment labour.

Patients without medical complications should be offered light diet and fluids in labour. They should then be starved after delivery until the 3rd stage is complete in case manual removal of placenta is necessary.
Care of patients under 17 weeks gestation will usually be on Gosfield Ward (A203)
(gynaecology) unless plan is made by Antenatal Screening Midwife to care for patient on
Labour Ward. Patients 17 weeks gestation or above will be cared for on Labour Ward
unless the patient requests care on the Gosfield Ward

Pain relief, and if necessary anti-emetics, should be readily available to patients at all stages of labour and post-natally. Liase with the anaesthetist regarding patient controlled morphine analgesia and if epidural analgesia requested/required. (Refer to Appendix C)

Parents may initially feel emotionally unable to see the baby (especially when death is unexpected) and need to be given time, privacy and support. The baby should be placed in moses basket, in or out of room, as parents wish. Use the Flexmort cold mattress and /or cold cot to preserve the baby's appearance and slow down deterioration to allow the parents more time to make memories with their baby. If the baby is being held for long periods by the parents or family, the cold mattress should be sensitively explained and placed under the baby while it is held or led in bed with the parents. Instructions for the Flexmort cuddle cot are found in each box.

Parents should be encouraged to see / hold baby if they wish, as soon as possible, (but each parent's views should be respected, and for some only one partner may wish to see the baby). Some parents may wish relatives / friends/ siblings to see / hold baby. Many parents change their minds about seeing their baby as labour progresses, and they should be aware that they do not need to make any ‘firm' choices. If the baby has been dead some time, or abnormalities present it can be helpful to sensitively describe to the parents what baby looks like to prepare them. Sometimes showing parents gradually a foot, and a hand, and letting the parents discover their baby slowly, can be helpful in this situation.

The baby should remain with the parents as long as they wish (using cooled mattress/cot to preserve baby's appearance) in an unhurried environment. Staff need to prepare parents for deterioration in baby's colour over time. Please be mindful that we must not make assumptons about what is best for the parents. Parents will often reach a point when they know it is time to say goodbye to their baby, and it is important for their emotional wellbeing that they make this decision not us.

All babies should be sensitively presented to the parents using the different sized cribs and blankets available. There are pockets and wraps for smaller babies that cant be dressed. Please do not use vomit bowls, bed pans or kidney dishes.

At later gestations, if the baby's condition allows, parents should be offered the chance to bathe (if postmortem not required) and dress their baby. Parents should be informed that we have hats, clothing and blankets if they wish to use them or they can of course use their own.
Parents must be given a call bell to summon for assistance or support at anytime. If the mother is alone staff should check on her at least every 2 hours to offer physical or emotional support.
Partners should be offered accommodation (i.e. double bed, beanbag or reclining chair) and visiting should be unrestricted for family and friends.
Explain all procedures and investigations, documenting verbal consent where appropriate and keep records as clear and contemperaneously as possible.

Explain the SANDS (Stillbirth & Neonatal Death Charity) teardrop sticker to parents and following verbal consent complete the SANDS sticker and attach to the outside of the patient's maternity records and the main hospital folder. It can also be used inside future healthcare records with the patient's permission.
The baby and placenta should be examined by the midwife once the patient is comfortable. Please Document :

Sex of the baby or if indeterminate (under 20 weeks) there must be documented evidence that the parents have been informed it isnot always possible to determine the sex correctly and that later investigations may reveal the baby is of the opposite sex.
Weight of baby, if there is evidence of maceration, unusual features, knots in the cord, or retroplacental clots. If the baby has dysmorphic features medical staff should be consulted.
Head circumference and baby's length can be recorded for parents informaton.

Ensure the baby is labelled with 2 name labels. Use maternal details if <  weeks or stillborn and always use 3 different identifiers (name, hospital number and DOB). For a neonatal death, use baby's own details (still 2 labels, 3 points of identification on each), but also secure a label showing ‘baby of [maternal details]'.
The obstetric consultant and Professional Midwifery Advocate should be informed for all unexpected deaths and a DATIX form completed on the intranet.
Management of the 3rd Stage following Pregnancy Loss

The 3rd stage of labour should be managed according to the normal labour guidelines (Refer to the guideline for the ‘Management of normal labour and prolonged labour in low risk patients'; register number 09079). At earlier gestations the placenta can deliver spontaneously after the fetal delivery, in these circumstances oxytocin 10iu intramuscularly can be administered after the placenta has delivered.

For all gestations medical assistance should be sought from the obstetric registrar/consultant on call if the 3rd stage is incomplete after one hour ; or before this time if any active bleeding is observed or other concerns prevail.
If the patient is observed to be bleeding, immediate action should be taken by informing the obstetric registrar/consultant on call, the Delivery suite co-ordinator and the anaesthetist.
Under no circumstances should the patient await a delayed 3rd stage of more than 3 to 5
hours if the placenta remains in situ. (Refer to the'Guideline for retained placenta' ; register number 04245)
Post-Mortem (PM) Examination

Parents should be given time to read the Sands Bereavement Support Book, and directed to pages 27-36 “Understanding why your babdy died”. (Found in the front of the fetal loss paperwork file) and the Broomfield Patient Leaflet about Post Mortem at Addenbrooke's Hospital. This is where all our babies requiring post mortem go from Broomfield Hospital as they have a Perinatal Pathologist there.

Under  weeks gestation it may be viewed as being of limited value, but parents should still have the opportunity to discuss their views and request a post mortem examination. Pathologists can undertake Post Mortem from  weeks gestation to gain information for parents and examine the causes of fetal demise.

The consultant, obstetric registrar, or Bereavement Midwife (who have received training in obtaining such consent) should discuss the post-mortem examination with all parents when Intrauterine death isunexplained. National guidance is that Post Mortem should be recommended. This should be done with the partner or patient's choice of accompanying relative/friend present, and after they have recieved written information about postmortems. This is a very sensitive area and parents may decline such an examination. However it is important to explain the importance of this procedure and encourage them to give it serious consideration. If the parents are keen to go home before the consent for post mortem can be taken, the bereavement midwife may be able to visit the parents at home the following day to complete (if on duty).

There are three options for Post Mortem: Full Post Mortem – which will give the most information and looks at every part of baby internally and externally. External post mortem – This does not involve any incisions just external examination and internal imaging. Or Selective post mortem – Parents can give consent to look at a selected part of baby only.

Parents should be offered this examination at a second discussion if they decline; it should be explained that this is not to pressurise them into making a decision, but to offer them a chance to change their mind.

The NHS “Post-Mortem consent form – your wishes about the post mortem examination of your baby” (refer to appendix I,J,K, L) needs to be completed by senior medical staff and copied x3 (xin the notes, x 1 to the parents, and the original copy is sent with baby to the hospital performing the post mortem. If the parents are eager to go home and undecided about having a post-mortem, the Bereavement Midwife is also trained to take consent and can complete this form at home with the parents.

The signature of the mother is required on the PM consent form and all accompanying paperwork, and baby labels must match the maternal details unless the baby is a neonatal death (see below). The signature of the father alone is not acceptable, regardless of marital status. If it is impossible to obtain a signature from the mother the case must be discussed with the hospital who will be performing the post mortem.

Neonatal deaths require the baby to be labelled x2, each with 3 points of identification (baby's own name, DOB and hospital number). In these cases the death certificate and funeral/cremation forms should also all be completed in the baby's name.
In the ‘changing your mind' section (page 2 of the postmortem form) the date to be entered should be agreed with the parents and is usually 48 hours, unless the parents feel they

need more time. The baby will not leave MEHT and Addenbrookes will not commence the postmortem until the date and time specified has passed. The contact person should be the labour ward co-ordinator on a direct dial number (ie 01245 513056) as well at the NetCall number 01245 362305 press 1 then  The co-ordinator will then be able to arrange any change either with Mid Essex admin team onor with Addenbrookes Pathology Services directly Tel 01223 348018.

The midwife or doctor on duty can arrange the post mortem by ringing Addenbrooks directly. It is acceptable to leave a clear message stating who and where you are and a return contact number. They can also be contacted if there are additional questions or requests from the parents, or for general advice. (Refer to Appendix A or J)

When a post-mortem is requested, the baby should be kept cool (use the cold mattress or cot in this situation) as soon as possible. Parents must be informed of expected changes in baby's colour and temperature, and that occasionally a very prolonged stay (more than a couple of days) on the ward may affect post mortem results.

Once the baby is ready to be sent to the mortuary and is labelled x2 (neonatal death baby's have an additional label with maternal details) dressed, and in a clearly labelled body bag and coffin (Refer to appendix M), contact the porters on Ext 6000, or place a request via TeleTracking. On arrival of the Porter, complete the mortuary property form that they will bring with them. (Refer to appendix N). Please include the clothes the baby is wearing along with any teddies, blankets, pictures, etc.

Once the baby has gone to the mortuary (or home if the parents are wishing), contact the maternity administrative co-ordinator in the maternity administration on extension 3345 (or the deputy in the screening office [ext 3433]); who will arrange transport to Addenbrook's for post mortem, as soon as all the relevant forms are complete. If the patient has not been discharged it is important that she understands when her baby will be sent for post-mortem.
The baby should be transported by an appropriate undertaker or licensed courier and should have the following documentation:
much information as possible;
do not add formalin (replacement pots to be ordered from histology extension

Every attempt will be made to reconstruct the baby so that viewing is still possible after a post-mortem examination. Incisions are made as discrete as possible, and with clothes and a hat on no scars can be seen. It would not be advisable for parents to undress the baby after post mortem however. Parents need to be prepared for his / her altered appearance and deterioration during the time taken for the post-mortem to be competed. If parents
request to see their baby after the post-mortem, they should be informed that the baby should be returned to Broomfield Hospital in approximately 10 days.
Written post-mortem results take approximately 8-12 weeks from the date the post mortem is performed.
Parents should also be aware that a post-mortem examination can delay the funeral by as much as 2-3 weeks.

Coroners post mortem - If baby is going for a Coroner's post mortem we DO NOT need to complete a post mortem consent form and the coroners officers will make all the arrangements. The Coroner will want baby to be taken to the mortuary as soon as possibe, often within 24 hours, so please allow the parents to make as many memories and spend as much time with baby as possible during this time. It is vital that when a post mortem is needed that the cold cot and Flexmort cuddle pads are used, and baby is kept in, or on, one of these at all times.
Additional Investigations
(Refer to Appendix F, G and H)

Samples are important for obtaining accurate information for patients' follow-up, Teardrop appointments with the consultant (usually at 12-16 weeks) and for the study of the causes of perinatal mortality. In certain circumstances it may be difficult, impossible or inappropriate to obtain certain samples.
When samples are taken the relevant box on the checklist should be ticked. If samples are not taken then a comment should be made. (Refer to Appendix F and G)

Investigations are appropriate for all unexplained fetal loss – but not for most medical terminations, unless requested by the obstetric registrar or consultant. This will usually have been decided with the couple, and screening midwife antenatally, and should be documented in the handheld patient records. If unsure discuss with obstetric registrar/consultant on call.
Parents must be informed that whilst investigations may be performed it is not unusual for the cause of death to remain unexplained.
Bacterial swabs from the baby (ear, throat and umbilical) and placenta (fetal and materal
sides) are requested electronically on review, please give clear clinical details. Swabs are
not required for medical terminations unless infection suspected. (Refer to Appendix G)

Blood tests obtained from the patient should be taken on diagnosis of an IUD. Request electronically giving clear clinical details and using the Fetal Loss Profiles on Review – see maternal investigation form Appendix F.

A group and save blood sample should be taken from all patients, and full thrombophilia screening is recommended for unexplained pregnancy loss >20 weeks gestation or recurrent (not single event) miscarriage – please discuss with Obstetric Registrar or Consultant. This is done at 8 weeks after delivery. The mother is to be given a blood sciences request form with clinicial details, and a request for Thrombophilia profile which can be printed electronically on Review. This test must be undertaken at Broomfield
laboratory, and is best in the morning. Results can take 4 weeks to be reported on and will
be followed up at the consultant appointment or by the Bereavement Midwife and patient informed. (Refer to Appendix F)
Consideration should be given to any other bloods that may be required for co-existing conditions such as infection, pre-eclampsia, thyroid function or diabetes.

Cytogenetic testing is perfomed on a cord/placental wedge sample. Please cut a 1-2 cms wedge near to the cord insertion site, making sure it contains placental tissue, membrane and cord if possible. It offers the parents the opportunity to rule out genetic causes of fetal loss and is especially useful (along with maternal bloods and swabs) when the post-mortem is not requested or indicated (refer to Appendix I).

Verbal explanation of the test should be given to the parents so that they are aware of the wider issues involved when a family member (ie their baby) is tested for genetic screen and their verbal consent for the test should be documented in the patient notes/checklist.
A wedge shape sample taken at the cord originis more likely to provide successful results than skin samples.

All babies having a post-mortem should have a cord sample sent for genetic testing, if it is not possible to obtain a cord/placenta sample then a request for cytogenetic testing should be made clearly on the postmortem clinical details sheet.
Cytogenetic testing is not indicated if chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis has already been performed, unless the baby has features that do not fit with the orginal genetic results.

Specimens should be placed in a dry sterile universal specimen bottle, labelled and sealed with wax tape. This is then placed in a larger secure tube, and placed in the designated cardboard box with request form. (These are kept on labour ward, in the bereavement storeroom and/or antenatal clinic). Please send as soon as possible to the regional cytogentics laboratory at Regional Cytogenetic Lab, North East Thames Regional Genetic Service, Great Ormond Street, Specimen Reception, Level 5, Barclay House, 37 Queen Square, WC1N 3BH. Telephone: 0207 813 8561. (pre-prepared box with stickers on should be available in the bereavement store room but there are more stickers in the trolley to assist with labelling and more available from the maternity secretaries) The sample must be accompanied by the regional cytogenetics laboratory request form (refer to Appendix I).

If a delay is unavoidable the specimens should be stored in a +4C refrigerator (located in the dirty utility room on labour ward). Samples must not be placed in formalin. If a delay of more than  hours is expected the sample may be placed in normal saline. The Labour Ward Co-ordinator must be informed of the presence of a specimen in the fridge and a note made in the labour ward diary of the following weekday if the sample is not being sent immediately.

The Labour Ward Co-ordinator is responsible for sending the sample the following weekday by contacting the transport department ; telephone extension 4257 ; having first enquired if the antenatal clinic (extension 3433), or Gosfield Ward (extension 4921) have any samples to send that day.

Rhesus Prophylaxis – all Rhesus negative mothers require anti-D prophylaxis on diagnosis of miscarriage, medical termination, intra-uterine death and stillbirth as this is known as a sensitising event.
For all Rh Neg mothers obtain cord blood post delivery If possible and always take maternal blood for a Kleihauer post delivery, using the Rh Negative Anti D request form.
Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries (MBRRACE-UK) Forms

The Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries looks at all fetal deaths over 21weeks and 6 days gestation and requires the midwife to complete the MBRRACE Form, found in the pre- prepared paperwork file.
Once completed it is sent to the Bereavement Midwife by hand along with all the other paperwork.
Additional information and reports are available from www.mbrrace.ox.ac.uk

The MBRRACE Suveillance form is submitted online by the Bereavement Midwife using the information given on the form, and is then used as the basis for the PMRT (Perinatal Mortalty Review Tool) review (NPEU 2020), carried out for all cases of fetal loss after  weeks (Apart from TOP's).
Creating Memories

Parents have a small amount of time to make a life time of memories. It is important to gather as much information and offer as many keepsakes as possible – birth weight, length, hand and footprints (if possible), 3d hand and foot casting (undertaken by the bereavement Midwife team (if possible) a lock of hair (if possible), photographs (professional, and own), and save items of clothing, name bands and cot card for the parents to have tangible memories. These can be taken home on discharge, or be kept in the notes/ with the bereavement midwife, to have at a later date.

For all losses an appropriate sized memory box should be used, this will enable more information to be recorded and kept (these are available from Kolby's Footprints, SANDS, 4Lewis, Simba and other charitable groups, and are kept in the Blossom Suite nursery on labour ward).

Parents should be informed that it is usual for us to take photographs / hand and footprints / and possibly a lock of hair for them. Sometimes on babies of later gestations clay hand/foot prints may be possible and 3d hand and foot casting (These are done by the bereavement midwife and a consent form is required which is in the paperwork files). If they decline it must be clearly documented that the midwife has discussed that this is recommended practice ; as many parents who initially refuse later change their minds about photographs weeks or years later. If parents still decline this also needs to be clearly documented.

Photographs : There are several photographic services that we can offer to parents. The bereavment team have contact with an independant (but professional) volunteer. The hospital medical photographer can be contacted during office hours if the volunteer is unavailable, and the organisation ‘Remember My Baby' can be contacted by the midwife or parents (refer to appendix CC). Medical photography is usually used if photographs are

taken at a later time in the mortuary but the other services can also be asked as long as clear details given that the baby is no longer on labour ward. To request medical photography complete the yellow clinical photography request/consent card and contact the photography office on extension 4468.

If photos are taken with the Labour Ward digital camera parents should be given the memory card and pictures must then be deleted from the camera memory, some of the memory boxes also provide memory cards within them. Sometimes parents may wish to have photographs of themselves/ family with their baby, and are given choice as to what photo's are taken. Parents may also wish for assistance in taking pictures with their own cameras. There is also an Instax camera and film available for use, giving instant polaroid style photos.

If parents do not wish to keep photos they should be placed in a sealed envelope, clearly labelled and secured in notes, or may be kept by medical photography on their electronic system with a clear note in the patients notes as to their location. Photographs must never be sent to parents later in the post. If parents wish to come and collect them later, a midwife must be present when they receive them to prepare them and provide support. Or the Community Midwife or Bereavement Midwife can arrange to deliver them.

A Book of Remembrance is kept in the Faith room in the hospital. Any parent may have their baby's name written into this book, with a prayer or wording of their choice. Or they may wish to place an entry on an A4 sheet at a later date. Forms are in the paperwork files and can be given to the Bereavement Midwife or sent directly to the Chaplaincy team by the parents once home.
Baptism, Blessing or Naming Ceremony
Spiritual care should be offered to all parents, taking into account their religious beliefs.
The on-call chaplain can be contacted via swithboard or extension 5244, or the parents may wish for someone from their own faith group to be contacted.
A baby can only be baptised if he / she is alive, otherwise a blessing or naming ceremony can be performed.
After the ceremony the parents will receive the relevant certificate signed by a Chaplain.

Parents wishing to go home quickly may wish to return at a later date if the chaplain is unable to perform the ceremony before the parents leave, or may wish not to be present when their baby is blessed. If this is the case please document parents wishes clearly in the notes so that parents may be contacted, or not, as planned.
Maternity has a designated Chaplain that visits the ward every Tuesday to support our families and staff.
Parents should be made aware that they can come back and visit baby whilst baby is with us at Broomfield Hospital. This can take place in the mortuary viewing room or in the Blossom Suite.
Funerals

Parents should be given written information about funeral arrangements as soon as appropriate to allow them time to ask questions and decide on burial or cremation. Completion of the forms is simpler before the parents leave hospital, however for some parents this is too soon to consider and it must be made clear that they do not have to decide immediately. The Bereavement Midwife can visit at home to discuss. (Refer to the following link: http://meht-intranet/documents/patient-information/ )
Once decided the parents and the midwife complete a funeral arrangements form for each baby of any gestation. (Refer to Appendix O)

Unless the baby is a neonatal death all identification of baby and paperwork must state maternal details. Along with baby name labels, mortuary forms/cards, medical examination certificates if under  weeks, certificates of stillbirth and funeral arrangement forms, cremation and burial forms, and postmortem forms. Parents can fill in a section on the funeral arrangement form with the name they wish to give baby.
If the baby is a neonatal death then all labelling and paperwork needs to be in the baby's own name and with the baby's hospital number and the baby's date of birth.
Using the funeral arrrangements form ensures the parents instructions are clear about
whether they wish to be involved and / or contacted by the hospital funeral directors
(Richards of Witham) or whether they wish to contact and use a funeral director of their
choice. They may write extra instructions on the form for example if they would like the
ashes back and who can collect them. They can also contact Richards themselves, or ask
the midwife to on their behalf. Please ensure that the part of the form detailing who is
authorised to collect ashes does include the paretns themselves (if that is their wish). It is
not automatically assumed that parents will collect their babies ashes, and if parents' names
are not clearly documented then the crematorium can refuse release of baby's ashes. (Refer to Appendix O)
Parents should be informed that following cremation of their baby, ashes will be minimal
because of the baby's size; however each cremation at Chelmsford Crematorium is carried
out individually. They should also receive a copy of Chelmsford Crematoriums Memorial
leaflet (in paperwork file). (Refer to Appendix R).

Cremation certificates – if parents chose cremation (or are unsure at the point of discharge and plan to complete the funeral arrangements later) it is important to get cremation certificates completed by a doctor if it is a NND. In cases of neonatal deaths the doctor signing the death certificate should also be the first signatory on the cremation form, part 4, and a second unconnected doctor completes and signs the second part 5, (part 10 is completed by the crematorium). The midwife can complete the Cremation 9 form for a stillbirth.
Cremation Forms Cre9 (in paper work file) & Cre3 (completed by maternity admin) are required for stillborn infants ;
Cremation Forms Cre4, 5 and  (on the paper work files) are required for cremation of neonatal deaths.

Although Form Cre10 is attached to forms Cre4 and Cre5 it is completed by the medical referee at the crematorium, Cre13 is a separate form for stillbirths but is also completed by the medical referee at the crematorium

It should be made clear by attaching a note to the cremation forms if they have been completed before parents decided on burial or cremation. No additional cremation form is required for babies under  weeks gestation with no signs of life.

There are forms for ‘Application for Cremation' (Form Cre3 for Stillbirths and Form Cre1 for neonatal deaths, which a representative from maternity administration on extension 3345 has autorisation to complete and sign on the parents behalf. For babies under 24 weeks just a form 1C is required (refer to Appendix U).

If the hospital is arranging the funeral and wish for baby to be buried, parents will need to sign Appendix P. Parents opting for burial in a shared burial plot need to be informed that their baby cannot be exhumed at a later date to be buried individually should they wish. Parents will also need to sign (but not complete the form) a Cemetery Notice of Interment (refer to Appendix Q) If parents do not wish to have a shared plot, they must understand they will need to purchase an individual plot. A note to this effect should be put on the funeral arrangments form.
The Childrens Funeral Fund (Gov.uk 2019) helps fund funerals for children under 18. The money for the funeral is claimed by the burial or cremation provider directly.

If parents wish to take their baby home before the funeral they require documentation to show to any authority who may be involved with them, (refer to Appendix CC) and need sensitive guidance to ensure they comply with legal and environmental health regulations. If the baby is below  weeks and 6 days gestation they will require the medical certificate of examination to enable them to arrange a funeral on consecrated ground. (Refer to Appendices Z,AA,BB)

Memorial services are held in the Faith Centre (A209) as Broomfied Hospital twice a year in Spring and in Autumn. Patients should be offered a leaftlet reminding them when the next services will be held, and also the Faith Centre Contact number Ext  Anyone affected by pregnancy loss may attend these services.

Baby loss awareness week is every October 9th -15th, and the Blossom Suite Bereavement Team hold a wave of light ceremony, and have other awareness activities throughout the week with opportunities for parents to remember their baby and be involved.
Documentation / Certificates / Registration
Complete the patient's handheld records and Birth Register
Lorenzo System
Pregnancy < 24 weeks – the patient should be admitted and discharged as per protocol.
The baby does not get admitted if no signs of life and therefore does not get discharged ;
No hospital number is given to the baby and no NHS numbers ;
The birth details are entered in the back of the Birth Register ;
Stillbirths or live births of any gestation – enter in main section of Birth Register (mark SB or NND in red) ;
Stillborn babies are given a hospital number and NHS number ;
Neonatal deaths are given a hospital number and NHS number ;
Babies is linked to the mother on Lorenzo ;
Details are entered on Lorenzo as for any normal delivery or lower segment caesarean section.

For a ‘delivery <  weeks with no signs of life' include as much information for community staff as possible bearing in mind that the parents may read this letter. This is distributed to the GP and Community Midwife.

For a stillbirth (SB) or neonatal death (NND) Lorenzo should be completed as for a normal delivery or lower segment caesarean section (LSCS) as applicable. The NHS and hospital numbers will then be issued. The maternal discharge summary needs to include as much information for the community staff as possible.

For each NND, a ‘Child Death Notification Form' (Form A) must be completed electronically. It is the responsibility of the midwife to ensure this has been completed via https://www.ecdop.co.uk/EssexSouthendThurrock/Live/Public. A copy must be printed and delivered to the Bereavement ‘Blossom' Midwives team.
In the case of NND or Stillbirth, Child Health must be notified, usually by the ward clerk, on 0300 303 9996.They may also be contacted on provide.childhealth@nhs.net.

Registration: There is no legal registration required for a baby <  weeks but a ‘Medical Certificate of Examination' is required to enable a funeral to take place (Form 1C refer to Appendix U). This must be completed by a doctor or midwife who has seen the baby. Staff may complete a birth certificate from the Trust (in the paperwork file) for babies under 24 weeks.

Stillbirth – Stillbirth certificates (kept in a blue book in the bereavement paperwork trolley), should be completed by a midwife or doctor. No section should be left incomplete, and ‘unknown' or ‘none' entered if cause of death not determined. There is guidance for all sections in the front of the book. The midwife's or doctor's name should be clearly printed on the certificate and the counterfoil and a note of their name made in the patient's healthcare records. A stillborn infant should be described as male/female infant of ‘maternal details' on the stillbirth certificate.

Neonatal Death – a neonatal death certificate (kept on the neonatal unit, yellow book) must be completed by a paediatrician or when under  weeks an obstetric doctor, who has seen the baby both before and after death. The doctors name must be clearly printed on the counterfoil in the certificate book and a record of their name made in the notes. If no doctor saw the baby before death (i.e. non-viable gestations or when birth occurs before paediatricians can attend) then the doctors must discuss the case with the coroner before issuing a death certificate. A neonatal death certificate should show the baby's own name.
If the case becomes a Coroner's Investigation, DO NOT issue the death certificate or complete the cremation forms as this will all be done by the Coroner.
Stillbirth or neonatal death certificates are given to the parents in an envelope with verbal and written information about making an appointment to register their baby. They will then
be issued with the appropriate legal birth certificate and a certificate for burial/cremation (Refer to Appendix X).

Stillbirths must be registered within 42 days ; whereas neonatal deaths must be registered within 5 days. (if the coroner is involved sometimes the 5 day period may be wavered and this can be discussed with the coroners' and registry office).

Parents must be informed to bring the certificate for burial/cremation given to them by the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages back to the maternity administration (situated by the antenatal scan waiting room, or by hand clearly labelled to the main hospital desk). This will enable the maternity administrator co-ordinator (on extension 3345/3062) to contact the hospital undertakers. If parents are arranging their own funeral with their own choice of undertakers they take the form direct to their own undertakers. The funeral cannot take place until this form is received by the undertakers.
Postnatal Care
The patient must be advised on the physical changes to expect after birth and when to seek medical help. Post-delivery exercises should also be discussed and leaflet given. (Refer to Appendix JJ)

A postnatal visit by a community midwife should be offered and advised. The patients wishes should then be documented in the patient's healthcare records If the patient does not wish to see the community midwife, they should be given a contact telephone number in case they change their minds, or offerred a community midwife phone call. If they still decline a visit this should be documented, and they must be advised to see their General Practitioner (GP) within 10 days of discharge.
The community midwife should be informed verbally of the patient's wishes regarding postnatal visits.

The Bereavement Midwife can contact the family once home to offer further support and answer any further questions they may have. Home visits are also possible if the family would like. A letter from the Bereavement Midwife can be found in the paperwork folder to be given to the family with their contact numbers on (Appendix GG).

There are postnatal support leaflets in the paperwork folder to give to the patient on discharge. This contains written contact numbers for labour ward, appropriate support organisations, counselling services and the consultant secretaries (refer to Appendix II). The Sands support pack of leaflets or equivillent should also be discussed and given, removing any leaflets that are not relevent. All patients should be given the opportunity to see a senior obstetrician before discharge if they wish.

Explain to the mother that she may start lactating on the third or fourth postnatal day, depending on gestation and parity, and offer a once only dose of Carbagoline 1mg to suppress lactation. The brand used in lactation suppression states that carbagoline is ‘contra-indicated in hepatic insufficiency', and RCOG states to avoid in hypertensive/ pre- eclamptic women, therefore caution is advised in such patients. If deemed appropriate milk donation can be discussed, (please liase with the breastfeeding specialist midwife for more information on this).
As of July 2019 the Children's Funeral Fund was launched which means bereaved parents no longer have to pay the cost of their chids burial or cremation. Funeral providers will

instead be able to directly claim costs. Parents can also claim costs if they choose not to use a funeral director. The scheme is available regardless of family income and will cover costs for children under 18. The hospital does not charge parents for any funerals we arrange. (https://www.gov.uk/child-funeral-costs).

Maternity Benefits are not applicable if the pregnancy ends before  weeks and 6 days and the baby shows no signs of life. The mother should be advised to see their GP's for appropriate time off, and may qualify for statutory sick pay.

Statutory maternity pay or Maternity Allowance is also not paid unless baby is stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy, or is a neonatal death at any gestation. Statutory sick pay may be applicable and the patient should be advised to see her GP.

If the baby is stillborn after 24 weeks or is a neonatal death then the mother is entitled to full maternity benefits and leave. (Refer to the Department for Work and Pensions – www.dwp.gov.uk/lifeevent/benefits www.moneyadviceservice.org.uk or www.direct.gov.uk/FuneralPayment
On Discharge

Bereavement Midwife, Community Midwife, Antenatal clinic , Scan Department, General Practitioner and Health Visitor should be informed verbally once pregnancy loss has occured and before discharge. And an extra discharge sheet should be completed and placed in the Community Midwives Bereavement Discharges Folder in the low risk office, adding additional information that the community midwife can access.
All parentcraft classes, scans and appointments must be cancelled. The midwife must
document on the cancellation form when the parentcraft classes are booked, in order to
assist this process. (Refer to Appendix DD).
The applicable section of Appendix DD should be detached and sent by hand to Lead Midwife for Perinatal Mental Health informing her of pregnancy's ending in loss.
Due to GDPR, Bounty request that women contact them directly for suppression of their advertising services, to prevent the receipt of inappropriate advertising material. (Refer to Appendix EE)
Bereavement Midwife follow up book page to be completed (Appendix HH). Record as much information as possible.

The Labour Ward Coordinator must ensure the checklists are completed and all paperwork contains the same surname as the baby is labelled with (ideally the mothers but may be the baby's own details in cases of NND who have been cared for on the neonatal unit) and that the completed paperwork file is sent with all the notes to maternity administration office at Broomfield Hospital and must include the following :
Funeral arrangements form ;
Certificate of Medical Examination (if < 24 weeks) ;
Cremation certificates if > 24weeks (if cremation planned or if parents are undecided at time of dishcharge) ;
Shared burial plot form (if for burial or if parents are undecided at time of discharge but know that they do not wish an individual plot) ;
Post Mortem Consent / Request Form / Case details and scans/results and notes (if applicable) ;
The maternity administrator will then make arrangements for the baby to go for post- mortem and contact the funeral directors (Richards of Witham – unless parents have made their own arrangements).
Follow-up Appointments

Consultant follow up appointments are arranged at approximately 12  weeks ; timing dependant on investigations and if a post mortem was undertaken. If no investigations were taken the appointment can be made for 8 weeks after delivery. The patient should be informed of how many weeks the appointment is likely to be, and that the exact time will be sent to them once all results are obtained. Parents can contact the Bereavement Midwives with any queries. Thrombophilia screening is done at 8 weeks if required and can take a further 4 weeks to be reported on. The Consultant will be responsible for ensuring this result is followed up. (Refer to Appendix F)
The notes initially stay on Labour Ward/ Maternity Admin/Bereavement Midwife Office, for the maternity administrator to ensure she has all necessary paperwork for funeral arrangments and postmortem.

The Blossom Team will check to see if parents would like a ‘Teardrop' appointment, and will liaise with the consultants secretaries to organise this, following the receipt of results of any investigations.
Staff Training and Support

All midwives and obstetricians should attend a bi-annual mandatory training session to include pregnancy loss to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained. (Refer to guideline for ‘Mandatory training services; register number 09062). Other bereavement study days will be made available every year taught by external agencies or by the bereavement midwife. Training for student midwives and preceptors is also offered. A quarterly bereavement update letter made available to all maternity staff will ensure all staff receives regular updates.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Staff involved in care should be familiar with the SANDS publication ‘Pregnancy Loss and the Death of a Baby' and have access to training and support for themselves.
Inexperienced staff will need support from the Bereavement Midwife and senior staff. Additional support is also available from the Trust's Psychotherapy & Counselling Service via occupational health.

Within Mid Essex Trust further support or advice can be sought by contacting the Antenatal and Newborn Screening Co-ordinator on extension 3433; or the Bereavement Midwife on extension 6314 or 07785956140, or via Professional Maternity Advocates, Chaplaincy team and the Manager on call.
National help-lines are also available to staff, as well as patients, for information and support including:
Antenatal Results and Choices (ARC) www.arc-uk.org
Tel 0207 713 7486 Email: info@arc-uk.org
Child Bereavement UK – Information and Support Line: www.childbereavementuk.org
Telephone: 0800 028 8840
9am – 5pm Monday-Friday. Or
Stillbirth and Neonatal Death Charity (Sands) – www.uk-sands.org
Telephone : 0808 164 3332
helpline@uk-sands.org
Please see Appendix KK for full list of support groups.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practicing midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection Prevention

All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure; refer to ‘Hand hygiene policy; register number 04072.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff with embedded icons to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's staff newsletter that is sent via email to all staff.

I4 Guidance
Notes for completing the Abortion Notification form I4 (revised Nov. 2002)
Background
Registered medical practitioners are legally required, under the abortion act 1967, as

amended, to notify the chief medical officer (CMO) of every abortion performed in England and Wales whether carried out in the NHS or an approved independent sector place and whether or not the woman is a UK resident. The Department of Health provides form I4 for this purpose.

In Autumn 2000, the department sought views on changing the format and content of the abortion notification form I4 (a copy of the consultation letter can be found www.doh.gov.uk/abortionact.htm). as a result, the I4 was amended in 2002 for use in England from th April and in Wales,th December.
Completing the Form

This revised form has been designed to be electronically scanned and for certain information to be read across into a database. It is therefore important that all numbering and writing are kept within the boxes and that boxes that do not need to be completed are kept blank. Please enter dates in day/month/year format e.g. 18/04/2002. As the forms will be scanned, we would prefer sticky labels not to be used. However, if they are, please ensure that the label fits within the box provided. If rubber stamps are used, please ensure that the stamps are legible.

Further guidance on completing the form can be found overleaf. One aim of redesigning the form was to make it easier to complete as a significant number of forms received are incomplete or inaccurate, and in some instances illegible. Please note that incomplete forms will be returned to either the practitioner terminating the pregnancy or to the place of termination. If the forms are not returned within 6 weeks, reminders will be sent. Incomplete forms generate additional work for those completing the forms and for those who process them on behalf of the CMO.

data.text: Appendix J
Post Mortem Referrals to Addenbrookes
Referrals

Any midwife/doctor can ring and book a post mortem. Either speak to or leave a message on 01223 348018. Babies can be sent even if you have only left a message but they will not be sent until the date and time that is specified on the PM form for the parents to change their minds has passed.
They are open Monday to Friday 9am – 5pm
Post mortems are not undertaken on a Friday, but the department is open babies can still be sent on a Friday
They will undertake post mortem's on medical not surgical TOP fetus' / babies after  weeks gestation
Babies may still be transported by ambulance courier

Baby must be sent under mothers name unless they are a live birth and then they must be sent under the babies own registered name (essential all paperwork for funeral and PM have same identification as baby labels)
For cytogenetics analysis of cord / placenta continue using Cytogenetics in London – if sample impossible to collect Addenbrookes can be requested to carry out cytogenetic testing
Paperwork
An NHS Consent Form must be signed by the mother if this is a miscarriage, TOP or Stillbirth

Complete the Addenbrookes Post Mortem Request Form (case details), Addenbrookes Checklist, and Addenbrookes Mortuary Property Form, and attach a copy of Negative Covid Swab result (Babies of mothers with a positive Covid result are still entitled to have a post mortem undertaken, but Addenbrookes should always be contacted first).
Please send any scan reports, amniocentesis/CVS results or identify any outstanding results that may be applicable
Transporting Babies
Place 2 x name bands around stomachs of small babies / fetus', and around ankles / wrists for bigger babies (maternal details on baby's name band and on post-mortem form – mother to sign)
Fresh dry placenta in a leak proof bucket / container

All babies from labour ward to be dressed if big enough, otherwise put in specially made wrap/sleeping bag. Baby to be placed in body bag and then cardboard coffin with mortuary identification card on both (no need to wrap in plastic).
Additional contact details
Administrative Coordinator 01223 348018
Fax number 01223 348022
Babies should be back within 1 week Written reports take up to  weeks

data.text: Appendix T
MID ESSEX Women and Children's
Parental Burial / Cremation of Baby after Miscarriage (Information for parents)

This guidance is only applicable to babies born before  weeks and 0 days with no signs of life and parents need to be aware the hospital or an undertaker of their choice can offer burial or cremation in consecrated ground.
Babies born with signs of life or after 23 weeks and 6 days have to be buried or cremated by a registered undertaker and this document is not applicable.
Some parents may choose to bury or cremate their baby under  weeks themselves without official status and this is within the law but we would like to advise you of the following:
They must own any land where they bury the body
The burial / cremation must be recorded in any deeds for said land
There must be no ongoing coroners enquiry
They need to have received an appropriate letter from the hospital
The local environment agency must be infomed of proposed burial / cremation in case of contamination of any underground water routes, drains
Parents have signed an official release form for their baby's body
(Refer to Appendix DD)
The family should be advised to consider how they would feel if they had to leave the land where the baby was buried / cremation
Parents may wish to consult with the hospital chaplain or their local faith representative to discuss suitable service options

data.text: Appendix V
Broomfield Hospital Women and Children's
Registering a Stillbirth or Neonatal Death
Your baby needs to be registered at the Registrar of Births and Deaths at 17 Market Road, Chelmsford (near to the library), or an office of your choice if it is within the district.
It operates by an appointment system and is open
Monday – Friday 09.30-17.00
Saturday appointments not usually available on Saturdays for registering stillbirths or
neonantal deaths but may be possible on phoning
or online www.essex.gov.uk  or Tel 03457 430 430

You will need to take the ‘Certificate of Stillbirth' or ‘Neonatal Death' with you (labour ward staff will give you this certificate) and after registration you will be given a ‘Certificate for Burial or Cremation' by the Registrar.
A funeral cannot proceed without the Certificate for Burial of Cremation that the registrar will give you once you have registered your baby.

If you have asked the hospital to arrange the funeral the certificate for burial or cremation needs to be handed to reception in Antenatal Clinic at Broomfield Hospital Level 4 (A401) or if you are arranging your babys funeral to the funeral director you have chosen
Neonatal Deaths must be registered as a birth and a death within 5 days from the date of delivery. Stillbirths must be registered within 6 weeks.
The Hospital Chaplain is available to all parents, or we can contact your own Minister or Priest if you prefer at any time.

Appendix X
Neonatal Death? No need to stress!
Please follow these steps for ANY baby at
ANY gestation that shows signs of life and then dies:
Do not issue death certificate, do not put placenta in formalin, and do not send for PM until Coroner is happy for you to do so.
(Unless coroner is investigating, in which case the time limit is wavered).
Appendix Y
Support Required from Paediatricians in the event of all NND (including non-viable) on Labour Ward
During this distressing time for parents and staff, the support from the Paediatric team is essential to enable a smooth and timely process in the best interest of our families.

ANY baby at ANY gestation born with signs of life, that then die, have to be registered as a live birth and then as a neonatal death. These babies are registered as a NND just like any other baby over 24 weeks. This is a legal requirement, and at Broomfield hospital we make sure the correct process is followed, and it is everyone's responsibility to make sure this happens.

The Paediatric team may have reservations in attending a pre viable delivery, however if called to assist, there is no expectation for the Paediatrician to do anything for baby. However, there are some very important documents and support that the Paediatric team will be needed to help us with. This may involve seeing the baby alive and certainly seeing the baby once passed.
The Paediatrician may be asked to come and talk to parents prior to delivery if appropriate, to help them understand why a pre-viable baby will not be resuscitated and is not compatible with life:

‘At 22-23 weeks, ‘standard practice should be not to resuscitate the baby'; by 24-25 weeks, ‘normal practice' should be to offer ‘full invasive intensive care and support' unless the baby is in a very bad way. At 23-24 weeks, ‘it is very difficult to predict the future outcome for an individual baby', and precedence should be given to the wishes of the parents, unless the clinician feels that treatment is futile.' BPAS

The Paediatrician will be required to complete the Crem 5 form, which needs to be completed by a doctor from another speciality than the one signing the Crem 4 – which will be the Obstetrician on labour ward. The Crem 5 is just confirming what the doctor has written on the Crem 4 form and involves a discussion with that doctor, seeing the baby once passed, and signing a declaration of truth.

In the unusual situation where the Paediatrician is present instead of the obstetrician (which will be our first port of call if no resuscitation will take place), then the Paediatrician will be asked to fill out the CREM 4 instead, and the death certificate as the doctor who has seen the baby alive and then passed. Just as would happen on the NNU.
Appendix Z
MID ESSEX HOSPITALS SERVICES NHS TRUST Women's and Children's
Taking your Baby Home after Death (Information for Parents)
Guidance for parents who wish to take their baby home after death without initially involving a funeral director or before a funeral service.
It is not advisable to take your baby home if a post-mortem is to be undertaken. However staff can discuss taking your baby home after post-mortem examination.
We advise that you consider and discuss with staff / hospital Chaplain the pros and cons of taking your baby home, including the impact this might have on other members of your family.
Staff can arrange for the on-call, or your own, Chaplain to see you before you leave hospital to discuss funeral arrangements for your baby and advise on burial / cremation options.

Legal documentation to enable a funeral to take place will be given to you. A medical certificate if under 24 weeks OR instructions and certificate to take to the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages if over  weeks. There are additional forms if you wish to have your baby cremated. These forms will then need to be given to your undertaker if you are arranging the funeral.

Your baby will need to be wrapped or dressed in gentle cotton cloths or clothing and then a shawl or cotton sheet whilst you take him/her home. Staff will discuss with you how to care for your baby. We advise keeping him/her in an unheated room, and supervise young children or pets.
Please discuss any further details with the midwife. Labour Ward contact number is Tel: 01245 362305, select 1, then select 1 again – please ask to speak to the labour ward coordinator

Appendix FF
Foot/hand Casting
The Bereavement Midwife has undertaken training to be able to offer you the opportunity to have a 3D cast made of your baby's feet/hands to treasure forever.
The skill is still being perfected, and although they may not be perfect, you will have casts created with love and care, and we are confident you will be pleased with them.
This is offered free of charge and is funded by donations from local groups and parents.
We feel this process is mainly suitable if your baby is born over 24 weeks, however suitability will be considered, and assessed, on a case by case basis.
The casts can take up to 1 month to complete due to drying and painting times and Tabitha with contact you when they are ready and arrange collection/delivery.

Appendix II
Useful Contacts for Support and Information Following the Loss of Your Baby

Picking up the phone and talking to a stranger can be daunting, it doesn't matter if you don't know what to say, or what you want. The people on the end of the line are there to help you work it out. You can also hang up whenever you want, even mid sentence!
Broomfield Staff Support

Your Bereavement ‘Blossom' Team are Tabitha Stuthridge, Max Ridley-Snell (midwives) and Lindsay Oliver (specialist maternity care assistant). We are available most week days (due to shift patterns) 8-17:00 on516314, Mob: 07785956140. We will always repond to messages as soon as we are next working; however, if you need anything urgently please call the labour ward staff on
Chaplaincy:
Tim Blake and team:

You should be contacted about an appointment with your consultant within 8-14 weeks after delivery dependant on the tests and investigations requested. If you need to check on your appointment or change it:
